name: io/http/express/Route handler

91ce9cc7-04d3-43af-81be-39747c4aaf61.name: app ID
91ce9cc7-04d3-43af-81be-39747c4aaf61.description:
The id of the express instance.

Example: 
"my-express-server"

929caaa1-7ba7-46bb-951d-869e82fd5e47.name: method
929caaa1-7ba7-46bb-951d-869e82fd5e47.description:
Receives the method to handle request for. 

Example:
"GET"

fe5ec9de-a1f8-459c-bc69-e2fbf17c722b.name: route
fe5ec9de-a1f8-459c-bc69-e2fbf17c722b.description:
Receives the route(s) to handle requests for. Route be specified as exact match (1) or as pattern match (2).

Example:
1) "/status" will just match "/status"
2) "/s*s" will match "status", "shoes", etc..

91981648-5a12-4061-8be8-3c43210193c7.name: response

452b5701-97ed-4e87-b58d-34ea209e802d.type:
{
"baseUrl": string, 
"body": any, 
"cookies": any, 
"hostname": string, 
"headers": {string:string}, 
"ip": string, 
"ips": string[], 
"method": ("GET" or "POST" or "PUT" or "PATCH" or "DELETE"), 
"originalUrl": string,
"params": {string:string}, 
"path": string, 
"protocol": ("http" or "https"), 
"query": {string: any}, 
"route": string, 
"secure": boolean, 
"signedCookies": any, 
"stale": boolean, 
"subdomains": string[], 
"xhr": boolean
}
452b5701-97ed-4e87-b58d-34ea209e802d.name: request
452b5701-97ed-4e87-b58d-34ea209e802d.description: Forwards the request to be processed.

38bfa33c-cddf-478d-bf52-0f4ec611e800.name: done
38bfa33c-cddf-478d-bf52-0f4ec611e800.description: Event triggered when the specified action has been executed.

794e50a8-d799-4d02-8446-ed7ba43a44ef.name: app ID
794e50a8-d799-4d02-8446-ed7ba43a44ef.description:
The id of the express instance the action was executed on. Emitted when the action was executed.
To be used when chaining multiple actions on the same express instance.

Example: 
"my-express-server"

12b5e681-073c-47bc-abb3-698530817f66.name: error
12b5e681-073c-47bc-abb3-698530817f66.description: Sends error information in case the request could not be handled.

description:
Receives requests on the specified route and dispatches the corresponding response.
You may also consider method specific route handlers for easier use.

Example:
1. "my-express-server"@0 received on `app ID`
2. "GET"@0 received on `method`
3. "/status/"@0 received on `route`
4. a client GET request received by express with URL "http://api.mydomain.com/status"
5. {
"body": "", 
"hostname": "api.mydomain.com", 
"method": "GET", 
"path": "/status", 
"protocol": "http", 
}@0 sent on `request`to other node for processing
6. {
  "status": 200,
  "headers": {
    "content-type": "application/json" 
  },
  "body": { status: "OK" } 
}@0 received back on `response` from processing nodes and sent out to the client
7.
- null@0 sent on `done`
- "my-express-server"@0 sent on `app ID`
